abstract.title: Purpose:
abstract.p: To evaluate the real-life safety profile of intravitreal dexamethasone implant injection for various retinal conditions.
abstract.title: Methods:
abstract.p: Retrospective multicenter analysis of intravitreal dexamethasone implant injections (700 µg) due to various retinal conditions including central retinal venous occlusion (1861 injections), diabetic macular edemaoedema (3104 injections), post-surgical cystoid macular edemaoedema (305 injections) and uveitis (381 injections). The eyes were evaluated mainly for the occurrence of adverse events such as glaucoma, cataract, retinal detachment and endophthalmitis along during the follow-up period .
abstract.title: Results:
abstract.p: A total of 6015 injections in 2736 eyes of 1441 patients (mean age of 65.7 ± 12.9 years) were in total analyzedanalysed over an average period of 18 months (range 6 months to 102 months). A total of 576 eyes (32.5 % of the phakic eyes) developed cataract requiring surgical intervention. However, visually insignificant cataract progression was observed in another 259 phakic eyes (14.6%) which did not require surgical removal. A total of 727 eyes (26.5%) experienced an intraocular pressure (IOP) rise of > 25 mm Hg, with 155 eyes (5.67%) having a prior history of glaucoma and 572 eyes (20.9%) having new onset IOP rise. Overall, more than 90 % of eyes with IOP rise were managed medically, and 0.5 % eyes required filtering surgery. Endophthalmitis (0.07%), retinal detachment (0.03%) and vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage (0.03%) were rare. There was no significant change in visual acuity (p = 0.87) and central macular thickness (p = 0.12) at the last follow upfollow-up.
abstract.title: Conclusion:
abstract.p: This is the largest real-life study assessing the safety of intravitreal dexamethasone implant injections in various retinal conditions. Cataract progression and intraocular pressure rise are the most common side effects, but are often rather easily manageable.

Author’s Contribution: All persons designated as authors qualify for authorship, and all those who qualify are listed. Each author has participated sufficiently in the work to take public responsibility for appropriate portions of the content.
SYNOPSIS

This study reports the safety of 6015 injections in 2736 eyes in real life situation. Most common side effects were cataract progression (32.5%) and intraocular pressure rise of >25 mmHg (26.5%), with only 0.5% eyes required filtering surgery.

Intravitreal therapy has been a major milestone in ophthalmology and become one of the most commonly performed ocular procedures.1 2 Macular edemaoedema is one the most common vision threatening complications of various retinal diseases including diabetic retinopathy, retinal vascular occlusion, uveitis and pseudophakic cystoid macular edemaoedema. Occurrence of macular edemaoedema in these conditions is thought to be of multifactorial cause with inflammatory cytokines and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) playing an important role.3

Corticosteroids have been used to treat macular edemaoedema given its multifactorial etiologyaetiology including inflammation.4–9 Intravitreal triamcinolone acetonide (IVTA) was initially used but has a high incidence of intraocular pressure rise and cataract progression, especially in younger patients.6–8 The necessity of repeated monthly intravitreal anti-VEGF injections for retinal conditions paved the way for development of sustained release implants, which slowly released the drug over a 3– to 6 month period. AmongstAmong the sustained release steroid devices, dexamethasone implant (300 or 700 mcg) (Ozurdex®, Allergan Inc., Irvine, CACalifornia) is the most widely used treatment modality.10–13 Following FDAFood and Drug Administration approval in June 2014, along with macular edemaoedema due to retinal vascular occlusions, the use of dexamethasone implant has been extended to treat conditions such as diabetic macular edemaoedema, non-infectious posterior uveitis pseudophakic cystoid macular edemaoedema.6–9 14–18

Efficacy and safety of dexamethasone implant in various retinal diseases has been proved in various clinical trials all over the world.18–22 Clinical trials are of a stringent inclusion criteria, follow upfollow-up schedules and retreatment protocols, however, in real life, the treatment is usually individualizedindividualised with the need for multiple treatments in few patients, longer or shorter treatment-free intervals depending on the disease etiologyaetiology and recurrence. Increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) and cataract progression are the major concerns with dexamethasone implant. Clinical trials such as ZERO and MEAD reported IOP rise of 20%– to 32% and cataract progression in 64%– to 67% eyes.19 20 Real -life studies by Blanc et al. and Meyer et al. reported 70.4% and 40% of IOP rise with 50% and 54.5% cataract progression respectively.21 22

However, so far safety data is reported from rather small cohorts. Hence, we aimed, to evaluate the safety profile of dexamethasone implants in real-life situations in a variety of retinal conditions by pooling data from multiple centerscentres across the world.

A retrospective analysis of cases from 25 centerscentres across the world was carried out. Patients treated within the period of January 2012 to December 2017 were included in the study. The study adhered to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki. Institutional review boards at each study sites approved this study. Data was collected from 2736 patients who underwent intravitreal dexamethasone implant (700 µg) for macular edemaoedema due to various retinal pathologies including diabetic retinopathy, retinal vascular occlusion, non-infectious posterior uveitis and pseudophakic cystoid macular edemaoedema.

Inclusion criteria included eyes which underwent dexamethasone implant for any indication with at least 6 months follow upfollow-up after the last dexamethasone implant injection. Previously treated (anti -VEGF, or laser) eyes were included in the study, however, none of the study eyes were concomitantly treated with anti -VEGF or laser during the study period. Eyes with concomitant treatment were not included in the study. Exclusion criteria included eyes with less than 6 months follow upfollow-up and lack of data about comprehensive ophthalmic examination.

The patient demographics; systemic history; previous treatment history; laterality; comprehensive ophthalmic examination details including best corrected visual acuity, phakic status, intraocular pressure recording at baseline and at the last follow upfollow-up; and occurrence of any ocular or systemic adverse events during the follow upfollow-up period were recorded. Details about the management of adverse event, number of injections needed and occurrence of side effects was also analyzedanalysed. The study eyes were also divided into previously treated and treatment naïve groups and a comparison between the occurrence of adverse events in these two groups was also carried out...

Intraocular pressure was recorded by the Goldmann’s applanation tonometry and an IOP of >25 mm Hg was considered as significant ocular hypertension.23 Best corrected visual acuity was measured in Snellen’s and was converted into logMAR for the purpose of analysis. The baseline and post treatment best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) were analyzedanalysed to look for statistical significance.

Progression of cataract was determined and the number of eyes with cataract requiring surgery was also documented.24 Occurrence of other side effects like vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage, retinal tears, retinal detachment, inflammation and endophthalmitis and were also recorded.

All the data was tabulated and analyzedanalysed statistically by the statistical software using SPSS vV.18.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA). Continuous variables were analyzedanalysed using descriptive statistics while pre- and post-implantation parameters were analyzedanalysed using Wilcoxon signed-rank test. GeneralizedGeneralised estimated equation was used to account for correlation between eyes. Regression analysis was performed using analysis of varianceANOVA to correlate various independent variables with BCVA at final visit and cataract progression. A P-p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant.

A total of 2736 eyes from 1441 subjects treated with 6015 dexamethasone implant injections were included. The mean age of the subjects was 65.7±12.9 years with 865 (60.64%) males and 576 (39.36 %) females. The demographics of the group at baseline are described in Table 1table 1. The mean duration of follow-up was 18.9±16.1 months (range: 6– to 102 months).

body.p: Subjects in our series were treated with intravitreal dexamethasone implants for various indications as stated in table 2 with diabetic macular edemaoedema (3104 injections), retinal venous occlusions (1861 injections), uveitis (381 injections), and post-surgical macular edemaoedema (305 injections) being the major indications (Table 2table 2).

body.p: Among all the study eyes, 1772 eyes (64.77%) were phakic at baseline, and rest were pseudophakic. Out of 1772 phakic eyes, 576 eyes (32.5%) underwent cataract surgery while 259 (14.6%) had cataract progression from baseline but did not undergo surgery during the follow upfollow-up.

Although the percentage of eyes with baseline cataract was greater in the previously treated group compared tocompared with the treatment naïve group (42.6% vs 27.8%, p=0.03), the percentage of eyes requiring cataract surgery did not statistically differ between two groups (31.7% vs 27.8%, p=0.24) (Table 3table 3). We found a statistically significant increase in cataract progression in eyes receiving more number of dexamethasone implant injections (p=0.004), although the co-relation co-efficient was small (r=0.057).

caption.title: Baseline parameters and side effects in the previously treated and treatment naïve patients.

td.p: Mean BCVA at follow upfollow-up, logMAR

body.title: Intraocular pressure rise
body.p: The average baseline IOP among the overall cohort was 15.31±3.00 mm Hg. At baseline 103 eyes (66.4%) were on anti-glaucoma medications (AGM) and 7seven eyes (4.5%) had a history of glaucoma filtration surgery. Intraocular pressure rise was present in 727 eyes (26.5%). Among these eyes, 155 eyes (5.67 %) had a prior history of glaucoma and 572 eyes (20.9%) experienced a new onset IOP rise during the follow-up. Among the patients with a new onset of IOP rise, 27 eyes (4.72%) had a transient rise in intraocular pressure without requiring any treatment, while 545 eyes needed anti-glaucoma treatment. In 525 eyes (91.78%) anti-glaucoma medications (AGM) for IOP control were administered, in 18 eyes (3.14 %) surgery were conducted and 2two eyes (0.35%) eyes required laser trabeculoplasty. We did not find any significant correlation between glaucoma progression and number of dexamethasone implant injections (p=0.187)

Prior history of glaucoma was present in 10.7% of the uveitic eyes (16/149 eyes), in 5.4% of eyes (77/1434 eyes) with diabetic macular edemaoedema and in 5.1% of eyes (27/526 eyes) with retinal venous occlusion.

The rise in IOP in the treatment naïve group was controlled with anti-glaucoma medications in 351 eyes (91.16%) while 12 eyes (3.11 %) needed filtering. In the previously treated group 277 eyes (91.4%) were controlled with topical anti -glaucoma medications and 13 eyes (4.29%) needed filtration surgery (Table 3table 3). Overall, more than 90% of eyes with IOP rise were managed medically, and only 0.5% eyes required filtering surgery.

Other ocular side effects noted in our series were vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage in 1one eye (0.03 %), retinal detachment in 1one eye (0.03% %) and sterile endophthalmitis in 2two eyes (7.3 %)). The following systemic conditions were noted in 1one patient each: herpes zoster, death due to renal failure, cerebrovascular occlusion, myocardial infarction and angina. However, these were stated as being unrelated to the dexamethasone implant.

The mean overall BCVA at baseline was 0.55±0.44 logMAR while the final BCVA was 0.55±0.44 logMAR with the mean change being 0.007±0.46 logMAR (p=0.87). Although, the overall change in BCVA was not statistically significant, the improvement in BCVA in the retinal venous occlusion group and the diabetic macular edemaoedema subgroups was observed to be significant (p<0.001 and p=0.047, respectively) (Table 1table 1). Baseline BCVA was one of the main factors correlating with the final BCVA on univariate and multivariate regression analysis (Table 4table 4). Mean overall central macular thickness at baseline and the last follow upfollow-up was 356±36 and 289±97 microns respectively (p=0.12).

body.p: The Iintravitreal dexamethasone implants were given pro re nata (PRN) in 2749 eyes, while other eyes received it on an interval ranging from 3 to 6 monthly basis. The mean number of injections was 2.09±1.75 (range 1 to 15) with repeated number of injections being required in 1298 eyes. More than 6six injections were required in 183 patients with the interval between injections being 3– to 4 monthly or on PRN basis.

Intravitreal dexamethasone implant as a therapeutic option for macular edemaoedema has an advantage over anti-VEGF in its prolonged duration of action.15–18 25 In our study we conducted a retrospective analysis of 2736 patients from 25 countries treated with 6015 intravitreal dexamethasone implants in total over a period of 5 years. The main aim of our study was to assess the safety profile of a large intravitreal series. In total 576 eyes (32.5% of phakic eyes) developed significant cataract requiring surgical intervention during the follow-up period. Cataract progression was observed in 259 phakic eyes (14.6%) which did not require surgical removal. The other common side effect noted was a intraocular pressure. A total of 727 eyes (26.5%) had intraocular pressure rise >25 mm Hg with 155 eyes (5.67 %) having prior history of glaucoma and 572 (20.9%) having new onset IOP rise. Endophthalmitis (0.07%), retinal detachment (0.03%) and vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage were other rarer side effects noted in our patients.

The GENEVA study was one of the first to show the efficacy of dexamethasone implant in eyes with retinal vein occlusion.26 In 15% of the study eyes the trial reported an intraocular pressure elevation of at least 25 mm Hg, peaking at day 60 and normalising by day 180 and more. Other studies showed an intraocular pressure rise in 12% to 27% of the eyes except for the study by Zarranz-Ventura et al. (82 eyes) and Meyer et AlMayer et al. (64 eyes) which showed an intraocular pressure rise of approximately 40% (Table 5table 5).27–31 The small sample size in these studies could possibly be the reason for the higher percentages observed. Malclès A et al. in the SAFODEX study reviewed charts of 361 patients who received 1000 intravitreal dexamethasone implant injection observed ocular hypertension (IOP >25 mm Hg or rise in IOP more than 10 mm Hg) in 20% of injected eyes and a recent study by Zarranz-Ventura et al found a cumulative probability of IOP rise of 30% in 429 eyes at 24 months, similar to our study.23 32 Filho et. Al.et al (study of 329 eyes) and Lowder et Al.et al (229 eyes) noted an intraocular pressure rise in only 7.4% and 7.1% cases with dexamethasone implant respectively.25 33 In our study intraocular pressure rise was noted in 727 eyes (26.5%), amongstamong which 103 eyes (0.13%) had pre-existing glaucoma and 525 (72.2%) eyes with post-injection intraocular rise required AGM for IOP control. Overall, glaucoma filtering surgery was required in 25 eyes (0.91%), amongstamong which 7seven eyes (0.9%) had pre-existing glaucoma and 18 eyes (2.47%) had new onset post injection IOP rise.

named-content.named-content: Comparison of safety profile between our study and other Dexamethasone implant studies

title.named-content: of safety profile between our study and other dexamethasone implant studies

td.p: Death due to chronic renal failure,
SchmitZ Kz et al ZERO study
Conjunctival hemorrhagehaemorrhage 24 (18.6) Conjunctival hyperemiahyperaemia 17 (13.2) Conjunctival edemaoedema 4 (3.1) Eye pain 3 (2.3) Headache 3 (2.3)

body.p: Although ocular hypertension is a known side effect of intraocular steroid injections, the IOP rise following dexamethasone implant could be managed by topical anti-glaucoma medications in 91% eyes, which was similar to other studies like the SAFODEX study (97% cases managed with topical AGM).23 We did not find any significant correlation between glaucoma progression and number of dexamethasone implant injections (p=0.187) in our study, similar to other studies which also showed that repeated injections of dexamethasone implant was not found to have any cumulative effect on the IOP.34 35 Younger age, male sex, Ttype 1one1 diabetes, pre-existing glaucoma treated with dual or triple therapy, and a history of retinal vein occlusion or uveitis were significant risk factors for ocular hypertension after dexamethasone implant injection in a multivariate analysis from the study by Malclès A et al.23 The MEAD study also observed that the IOP rise with intravitreal dexamethasone implant is mild and predictable with IOP peak occurring at 6– to 8 weeks and returning to baseline by around 3 to 4 months.36

Amongst 1772 phakic eyes (64.8%) in our study, 835 eyes (47.1%) were noted to have cataract with 576 eyes (32.5%) requiring cataract surgery on follow-up while 259 eyes (14.6%) had visually insignificant cataract not requiring surgery. The 12 month GENEVA study wherein the patients were treated with 2two injections of dexamethasone implant noted cataract progression in 29.8% eyes with 1.3% requiring cataract surgery. Studies have reported progression of cataract following intravitreal dexamethasone implants from 0.3% to 47% (Table 5table 5). The variations in the sample size and the follow upfollow-up periods could explain the wide range of cataract progression in the studies. Studies including eyes with uveitis showed a greater occurrence of cataract as uveitis itself could also predispose the secondary cataract (Table 5table 5). The large number of phakic eyes at baseline (64%) with 33.7% of them having cataract at baseline could explain the greater percentage of cataract in our series. Reid et al in their study found that the incidence of cataract after the first implant was 13.2% which increased to 45% and 60% after the 2ndsecond and 3rdthird implants . They observed significantly higher rates of cataract surgeries in the 2ndsecond and 3rdthird implant group when compared tocompared with the single implant group.34 Similar to their study we also found a statistically significant increase in cataract progression in eyes receiving more number of oOzurdex injections (p=0.004) although the co-relation co-efficient was small (r=0.057). Occurrence of sterile endophthalmitis following intravitreal dexamethasone implant was very low in our study (0.07%) along with other rarer side effects like vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage (0.03%) and retinal detachment (0.03%). Most of the studies did not observe side effects other than raised intraocular pressure and cataract. Endophthalmitis, vitreous hemorrhagehaemorrhage and retinal detachment were other rare adverse events noted in other studies similar to ours (Table 5table 5). A study by Li et al. noted conjunctival hemorrhagehaemorrhage (18.6%) followed by conjunctival hyperaemia (13.2%) as the other most common side effects in their series.27

AmongstAmong the various subgroups, the uveitic group had a lesser percentage of eyes with cataract at baseline (22.1%), however, the number of eyes requiring cataract surgery in this subgroup was higher (39.8%) compared tocompared with the RVO (28.9%) and the DME subgroup (31.0%) (Table 1table 1). Other studies with uveitis have observed occurrence of cataract ranging from 4.8 % to 15 % (Table 5table 5). Ozkaya et al. reported on 47% eyes with cataract in their study.37 Furino et al combined phacoemulsification and dexamethasone implant and proposed that it may be an effective approach for patients with cataract and diabetic macular edemaoedema.38 An elderly cohort and pre-existing cataract and uveitis could possibly account for the higher occurrence of cataract in the study populations.

Limitations of our study include the retrospective nature with lack of uniformity in treatment and follow upfollow-up protocol as it contains pooled data from all over the world. The strength of our study is the safety profile following a large number of injections (6015) in large number of patients in real clinical practice across the world.

In conclusion, our study of 6015 dexamethasone implant injections revealed visually significant cataract necessitating surgery (32.5%) and an intraocular pressure rise (26.5%) as the major treatable side effects of the implant. Among the patients with intraocular pressure rise, more than 90% were well controlled with topical anti-glaucoma medications and only 3.43% requiring glaucoma filtering surgery. Dexamethasone implant appears to be a safe in various retinal conditions in real -life situations.
